developmentplay_articles.text_1_facilitator::eng: Here are some tips to help you support your child as they learn and develop important skills.
developmentplay_articles.section_1_text::eng:
Play is the main way children learn and develop. Through play, they build important physical and social skills. 

Set aside time to play games with your child, be creative, and have fun together. Remember, through play, you also learn what kind of support your child may need.
developmentplay_articles.section_1_extra_text::eng:
You can support your child to play and make friends with other children, so they learn how to interact with others well. 

If your child starts to feel overwhelmed with anything in their day, help them reduce their stress by taking a pause and playing together.
developmentplay_articles.section_2_text::eng:
Learning new things takes time. Be patient and encourage your child to keep trying things they may find hard. 

Stay calm when they get angry or frustrated - your child will learn to do the same over time.
developmentplay_articles.section_2_extra_text::eng:
You can support them by praising them for trying, and helping them break large tasks into smaller tasks that are appropriate for their age.

Use play to help your child learn difficult skills, like losing, sharing, or taking turns.
developmentplay_articles.section_3_text::eng:
Children learn by asking questions and exploring the things they are interested in. Give your child time and space to do this, and be patient when they make mistakes. We all learn from our mistakes!

Join your child’s activities and ask them questions to encourage them to learn more.
developmentplay_articles.section_3_extra_text::eng:
Your child may talk a lot and have many questions - including difficult ones. You can give your child short but honest answers. 

If you need a break or more information, you can take a pause and tell your child you will respond to them later.

developmentplay_articles.text_1_facilitator::eng:

This week's home activity is to invite your child to play with you. Encourage them to ask questions and explore new things through play.

Today's topic is about spending one-on-one time with our teens. 

Being a parent can be so hard. Sometimes it feels like our teens never listen to us.

But science shows that spending just a few minutes each day of focused one-on-one time with your teen helps build trust and love.

oneononetime_t_articles.media_transcript::eng:
Hello.

Our topic today is one-on-one time with our children.

It is important to spend time with our children so that they can get to understand us, and for us to get an opportunity to understand them.

Remember, a family with good understanding lives in harmony.

oneononetime_t_articles.text_1_facilitator::eng:
Let's discuss, what is one-on-one time?

One-on-one time is when you focus on your teens, without distractions like TVs or phones. Let your teens take lead in choosing what you do or talk about.

It is great if you can spend fifteen minutes a day together, but even five minutes a day is really good.

First, it felt weird, but it turned out to be fun! Now we watch his TV programme together and we chat about it. And we can even talk about how my son is changing into adolescence and even about girlfriends and those things!

oneononetime_t_articles.text_1_facilitator::eng: Here are some skills to help guide you in spending one-on-one time with your teen!
oneononetime_t_articles.section_1_text::eng:
Try to do it every day. 

Find 5 minutes (or more!) each day when your teen does not have something else they want to do.
oneononetime_t_articles.section_2_text::eng:

- Review homework
- Chat before bedtime

feelings_articles.text_1_facilitator::eng:
Today we are learning to talk about feelings with our children. 

Noticing emotions, both our own and our children's, helps us care for ourselves. 

Noticing and talking about feelings with our children helps them learn to express and manage their emotions – even the difficult ones.
feelings_articles.media_title::eng: How will talking about feelings with my children help me and my family?
feelings_articles.media_transcript::eng:
Greetings, everyone.

Does your child ever get really angry upset and you don’t know what to do? 

You can help your child to manage their emotions better by showing them how to talk about their feelings. You start with noticing and accepting all the emotions we have. We are all human.

feelings_articles.text_1_facilitator::eng: With these three tips, you can help your child learn to manage their emotions well.
feelings_articles.section_1_text::eng: Recognise the *positive* and *difficult* emotions that you and your child feel.
feelings_articles.section_1_extra_text::eng: To recognise feelings, pay attention to your thoughts and to your and your child’s words and actions.
feelings_articles.section_2_text::eng: Be open to how you and your child feel. All feelings are okay.
feelings_articles.section_2_extra_text::eng:
There are six basic emotions. Each send us an important message:
 😊 Happy: Keep doing things that make you feel good. 

☹️ Sad: Something important in your life needs attention.

😠 Angry: Stand up for yourself and set limits.

🤢 Disgusted: Move away from something you don't like.

😯 Surprised: Stop and pay attention for a moment.

😨 Afraid: Run away from danger.
 
As children get older, they learn to identify lots of other emotions, like feeling excited, frustrated, proud, lonely, peaceful, guilty, or confused.
feelings_articles.section_3_text::eng:
Use words to describe your and your child’s emotions, so they can learn to do the same. 
 
This may be hard at first, but it is an important step to help manage emotions!
feelings_articles.section_3_extra_text::eng:
Describe how you see your child’s emotion in a calm way. For example:
 
*“I notice you’re stomping your feet, talking loudly, and your face looks a bit upset. Are you feeling angry?”*
 
Share your own feelings with your child. For example: 
 
*“I know I feel the same way when I can’t go out when I want to.”*
 
This shows your child that it's okay to share their feelings. They will learn to recognise emotions in themselves and others too.

grief_t_articles.section_1_text::eng:
Losing someone we love can affect us for weeks, months or years. There’s no right way to feel, and no need to feel better quickly.

Your teen may feel sad, angry, confused, or unwell. They may have nightmares, pain, or school problems. Even if they seem happy, they might still feel sad. This is all normal.
grief_t_articles.section_2_text::eng:
Find a way to say goodbye that feels right for you and your family. Some people hold a ceremony or have a special meal to celebrate the person.

Ask your teen what they would want to do to say goodbye.
grief_t_articles.section_3_text::eng:
Talking or writing about the person can help bring comfort. Gently share your memories—both the happy ones and the hard ones.

Teens may sometimes feel the death was their fault. Kindly remind them it was not. Let them know they can always talk to you about their feelings, and show them it’s okay by sharing yours too.

money_t_articles.text_1_facilitator::eng:
**Step 1: THINK**
Think about what you spend money on each month.
money_t_articles.text_2::eng:
- Draw pictures of all the things that you and your family spend money on each month.
- Write next to each picture how much each thing costs each month (there is no need to share the numbers if you don’t want to).
- Add up how much money you have to spend each month.

money_t_articles.text_1_facilitator::eng:
**Step 2: CHOOSE**
Think about your needs and wants.
- WANT is something you can live without. 
- NEED is something you cannot live without.
money_t_articles.text_2::eng:
Look at your list of things you spend money on and choose:

- Which are NEEDS that you cannot live without? Why?
- Which are WANTS which are nice to have but not essential? Why?
- Which things could you try to spend less money on?

- Write down what your income is for the month.
- Take some stones or beans or anything with lots of bits - this is your income for the month. For example: If your income is R2000 and you have 20 beans, each bean is R100.
- Decide what you will spend on, and put the stones/objects on that image.

Not sure about your decisions? Having trouble deciding between "needs" and "wants"? That’s totally fine! This exercise will get easier with practice.

money_t_articles.text_1_facilitator::eng:
**Step 4: PLAN**
Plan how you can save money, so you can deal with emergencies and realise your family goals!
money_t_articles.text_2::eng:
If you can save even a tiny amount for the future or emergency - it can make a big difference over time.

- Add a circle called “emergencies”.
- Add a circle called “family goals”.
- Now try to move your money around so you can save a bit every month for goals and emergencies.

I used to ask my mom to buy me nice clothes all the time. Each time, she would say “I do not have money,” but I knew that she was getting money from my uncle. I did not understand why she refused to buy me clothes. I thought at some point “she does not love me.”

But one day, she called me to sit down with her and asked “what are the needs and wants in our house.” I started to list all my needs and wants. Then my mother helped me to also think about the family needs. Now I understand where our money is going, towards the things we need as a family.

From that day, I understand I cannot come in and ask any time. Now, when I want something, I wait till the month-end when we all discuss the budget together to see if it fits. We understand each other better now.

instructions_articles.text_1_facilitator::eng: Here are three tips to give positive instructions that work.
instructions_articles.section_1_text::eng:
Say the behaviour you want your child to do.
But before you do that, connect to them, so they are more likely to listen.
instructions_articles.section_1_extra_text::eng:
Use your child’s name to get your child’s attention. Go down to their level. Make eye contact.

Then say exactly what you want them to do. For example: “Please take your shoes off when you come inside, dear”.
instructions_articles.section_2_text::eng:
Give one instruction at a time, and make sure that the instruction is something that your child can do. 

Giving a transition warning helps when you are asking them to change activities!
instructions_articles.section_2_extra_text::eng:
It can be difficult for your child to remember many instructions, so only give one at a time!

If possible, give a transition warning. For example: “In 10 minutes, you will need to pack away your toys so we can start getting ready for bed.”
instructions_articles.section_3_text::eng:
Try using positive words when giving instructions. For example, instead of “Don’t shout inside,” say “Talk in a quiet voice when we’re inside.”

ALWAYS praise your child for following your instruction. Remember that this will make them more likely to repeat the behaviour you have just praised them for, and listen to you next time!
instructions_articles.section_3_extra_text::eng:
Give instructions in a firm voice and stay calm. Behave as if you expect your child to do what you ask.

Praise, praise, praise! Make sure you praise your child immediately when they follow your instruction.

Also, be kind to yourself if you forget sometimes. Learning how to give positive instructions is not easy, but it works!

stress_t_articles.text_1_facilitator::eng: Here are a few skills to help you manage stress that you can use with your teens!
stress_t_articles.section_1_text::eng:
Breathe slowly. Pause.

Before you say anything, slowly breathe in and out five times. It will calm you, and give you a chance to think.
stress_t_articles.section_2_text::eng:
Share how you feel.

This is hard. Many of us were told not to cry, or show our feelings to our children. But take a deep breath and calmly tell them how you feel. They will understand better, and also learn from you how to deal with stress.
stress_t_articles.section_3_text::eng:
Show them you care.

This is also hard! Stress makes us focus on ourselves. But our teens need our support. Ask them how they feel. Listen to them and comfort them. Try a hug or say "I understand". It can change everything.
stress_t_articles.section_4_text::eng:
Seek the positive.

Can you and your teen think about ideas that might help? Can you do something positive together to take your mind off the stress?

Consequences are what happen after a child’s actions — good or bad. When children don’t follow a rule, parents can give a consequence to help them learn.

consequences_articles.text_1_facilitator::eng: Here are some easy steps to use consequences when your child misbehaves.

Then help your child work on the problem with you using these four steps.
problemsolving_articles.section_1_text::eng:
Put the problem into words.

Talk to your child about what the problem is.
problemsolving_articles.section_1_extra_text::eng: "I can hear you arguing because you don’t want to watch the same television programme. I know I said you both could watch TV after you’ve helped clean up after dinner but we only have one television set. What should we do about this?"
problemsolving_articles.section_2_text::eng:
Together, think of possible solutions to this problem.
What could you or your child do differently in this situation in the future?
problemsolving_articles.section_2_extra_text::eng: "One option is for us not to turn the television on at all. Or you could take turns choosing a programme. Or you could select a programme you both want to watch. What do you both think?"
problemsolving_articles.section_3_text::eng:
Choose one solution together.

Try it next time you are in a similar situation, and praise your child for trying!
problemsolving_articles.section_3_extra_text::eng:
The next day at after the dinner dishes are clean...
"Okay boys, do you remember what we said last night about the TV? Who can remember the solution we came up with?"
"That's right – well done for remembering! Let's try to pick a programme that you both want to watch – I may even come watch with you!"

problemsolving_t_articles.media_title::eng: How can problem solving help you and your family?
problemsolving_t_articles.media_transcript::eng:
Greetings, everyone.

Today's topic is problem solving.

We all know that in life there are times where we face problems, and we all know in a way that when we find ourselves in these situations, it is difficult to think of immediate positive solutions.

Therefore, it is important that when we are facing problems we take a pause, we breathe, keep calm and think of problem-solving skills that we may use.

Remember to include our teenagers when we are solving problems. This will help them to become responsible and learn how to solve their own problems in the future.

problemsolving_t_articles.text_1_facilitator::eng:
As parents, we sometimes think we need to fix every problem by ourselves. And teens can think the same! 

By involving your teen, you strengthen your relationship as well as their confidence. Together you can overcome anything.

problemsolving_t_articles.media_transcript::eng:
When my father introduced the problem-solving steps to me, it helped me with my family, but it also helped me with my friends.

I told my friends about the steps, and now when we are arguing we sit down and everyone comes up with solutions. We then look for the negatives and positives of each solution, and we agree “okay let’s try this one.”
